name: Micro 16s
keyboard: Full troke 98 keys with 10 function keys and numeric keypad
cpu: Intel 8086, Zilog Z80-A (standard), Motorola 68000, Intel 80286, Zilog Z8000 boards
ports: Parallel Centronics, Serial RS232, 4-channel A/D converter, RGB video, composite video, Light-pen
price: $3995 with colour monitor, CP/M-86, Wordstar and Supercalc?
description:
The Micro 16s was designed to be a powerful package of hardware and software in a professional business system. It offered a unique architectural design for the time: interchangeable microprocessors and thus operating systems. In fact most commonly used processors were Intel 8086 and Zilog Z80.

One or two processor boards could be plugged into the Micro 16s and either one could be in control of the bus, the memory, etc.
Fujitsu also planned to launch Motorola 68000, Intel 80286 and Zilog Z8000 boards.
RAM memory boards could be added, from 128 KB to 1024 KB, thanks to the new 256 K-bit RAM chips.
Fujitsu color graphics video terminal was handled by an independant video processor located onto the mainboard. A standard RGB monitor could be connected as well and used simultaneously.

With the Micro 16s, Fujitsu offered a very versatile system able to oparate all of the major microprocessors of the time, and run all existing operating systems.

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> MAIN BOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>8086 and Z80-A boards are plugged into the expansion slots.<br> Remaining slots could be fitted with: - Extra memory boards (slot 3) - Hard disk controller (slot 4) - Multiport serial communications (slot 5) - Local area network (slot 6) </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARACTER MODE</strong></font><br><blockquote>An example of the character mode.<br> Shown is a Supercalc² table.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BLOCK DIAGRAM</strong></font><br><blockquote>The 8086 processor is plugged into slot 1 and the Z80-A into slot 2.</blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT FROM NEW ZEALAND</strong></font><br><blockquote>In November 1976, the assembled basic version cost A$931, the unassembled version cost A$599.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (STUPID !)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Dated august 1982<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://wotsit.thingy.com/haj/">Howard Jones</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERTISEMENT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Isn't this funky ??!! I love it. We can see here the handle  of the H1.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Each day, go on the computing road''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (MAY 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>No info in this advert about the display that could be used (TV, composite, colour, B/W?)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ARGENTINIAN ADVERT </strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.speccy.org/czarg/" target="_blank">CZARG</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (FEBRUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"the power of words depends on the way you use them"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT#2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is another french advert, not from CBS, but from an independant store "le jeu electronique". <br><br> Only the expansion module #3 was available in France and people had to buy a Colecovision if they wanted to have an Adam !</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.cobit.kit.net" target="_blank">COB-Clube Old Bits</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JACQUARD BROCHURE #5 </strong></font><br><blockquote>The brochure says:<br><font color="#666666"> During Jacquard's early years, as a "system house", the company developed communications and peripheral devices that were not available from any other sources. Some of these are still available only from Jacquard. <br><br> Through these devices, Jacquard acquired hardware design and production skills, thus becoming experienced in integrating 'pieces' into systems that worked, and worked well. <br><br> These years of experience enabled Jacquard to design the first truly affordable and multi-functional small business system - the Jacquard Videocomputer... </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"TI 88/4A. The family computer.<br> It's easy. Connect it, connect yourself."</blockquote>

media: 1 to 4 x 320 KB 5.25'' floppy disc drives,  5 to 20 MB hard disk
peripherals: External 8'' or 5.25'' floppy disc and hard disc units
